text:
Matilda becomes a disturbingly effective tale of a child battling a world ruled by monstrous adults. The film’s cheerful colours only deepen the unease, turning every scene into something slightly uncanny.

Miss Trunchbull is a genuine horror villain—towering, sadistic, and atmosphere-warping in every appearance. Matilda’s telekinesis, instead of feeling whimsical, plays like a quiet haunting: objects moving with eerie calm, hinting at power born from neglect and fear.

What elevates it is the contrast between darkness and hope. Matilda’s final victory feels like a classic horror triumph, where the smallest, quietest character outlasts the monster.

Strange, unsettling, and unexpectedly powerful—Matilda works shockingly well as a child-centered horror tale.

All Time Classic. It's a shame this wasn't well received in 96'. It's difficult looking back to really understand why but sometimes gems like this fall through the cracks. It's a shame because man it would've been amazing too see what DeVito could do more of behind the camera. This is easily is crowning acheivement as a director. Fantastic direction in this. I love all the wide shots, how we see things from the view of a child, and how it changes as Matilda stands up for what's right representing her arc. Just first rate all around. Amazing cinematography and incredible practical effects that hold up remarkably well. Matilda is easily the best thing about this and is so charming, quirky, likeable, and good person beyond her years. Miss Honey is awesome too. Everyone else is really good too. This is basically if someone literally took the idea of Carrie and made it into a fantasy family comedy. It weaves effortlessly between being comedic, wholesome, and scary at times too. Just enough where it should'nt terrify little ones. DeVitos narration is excellent too and gives it more of a fairy tale feel as well. Wholesome, charming, and very original this is something everyone should give a watch once.

I first watched this movie in preschool and barely remembered it so I now wanted to rewatch it as an adult. This is a very creative and unique movie that is very good for kids, particularly for younger girls. Pam Ferris gives and incredible performance and Danny Devito as the director gave the movie a different and artistic flavor as well. This movie teaches pretty decent values to children overall, and who would’ve thought that a hiding and running sequence throughout a big home could’ve been shot, edited, and executed so tense yet so rich with entertainment?! Sure some parts of the movie are silly and ridiculous, but it can’t beat out its charm!

This is quite a heartwarming film/movie about an adolescent girl who was given birth by a family who wasn’t great and didn’t take her to start school, but once they did, she was taken to a school whose headmaster was a cruel, grumpy woman who physically punished children since there were no laws against it.
But the ending is very fulfilling, with Mrs. Honey becoming Matilda's parent/caretaker through adoption, as well as the school's new headmaster.

Matilda is hands-down one of the best family movies of all time. It has good lessons, great characters, and even better writing and direction. It was my favourite movie as a child, and it will forever have a special place in my heart.
